docs.lead_paragraph: A woman in the rural Midwest and a woman in an East Coast city receive identical breast-cancer diagnoses. Yet the East Coast city dweller has a lumpectomy, removal of just a part of her breast, while the entire breast of the rural woman is surgically removed. Why did the treatments differ? Questions like this involving the outcome of treatment have recently become the focus of women's health experts seeking to define the best treatment for various medical problems.
docs.abstract: Society for Advancement of Women's Health Research has found regional and demographic variations in medical treatments for women; Phyllis Greenberger, director of society, says people in one part of country get more invasive treatment than people in another part of country; says society's 'outcomes research' attempts to determine why that is and then disseminate findings (Special Section: Women's Health) (S)

keywords.value: SOCIETY FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF WOMEN'S HEALTH RESEARCH

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gail Heinze delivered identical twin boys in May 1996, at Southampton Hospital on Long Island, she used natural-childbirth techniques without anesthetics. Forty-three hours later, Ms. Heinze, a dental hygienist, and her babies were discharged from the hospital. Her managed-care provider, Group Health Insurance, didn't cover a longer stay. ''I was terribly weak and bleeding profusely,'' Ms. Heinze said. ''I needed more rest. Four or five days in the hospital would have been about right. As it was, it took me a year to recuperate totally.''

headline.main: How Long Should New Mothers Remain in the Hospital?

docs.abstract: Doctors say new Federal legislation requiring health insurers to cover no less than 48-hour hospital stay for new mothers and their infants has had positive impact; but even with the protection of law, new mothers' readiness to go home within a certain time can vary, and managed care companies may not always be open to longer postpartum stays; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: REPUBLICANS can usually win when they can position themselves as the guardians of low taxes and small government. By the same token, Democrats have the advantage when they can frame an issue as one involving the protection of children.

headline.main: The Nation; Politics of Tobacco: Taxes vs. Kids

docs.abstract: Senate debate on newly shelved tobacco bill pitted Republicans, who attacked it as tax measure, against Democrats, who defended it as way to protect children; Republicans won in part because tobacco industry mounted massive advertising drive focusing on tax issue; Democrats lost in part because they allowed focus to shift from children to weaker issue of punishing tobacco companies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: REPUBLICANS can usually win when they can position themselves as the guardians of low taxes and small government.    By the same token, Democrats have the advantage when they can frame an issue as one involving the protection of children.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Gov. George E. Pataki angrily disclosed a $42 million payment to the chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company earlier this month, he denounced it as ''an extraordinary secret act of greed.'' The payment, he insisted, violated the state's agreement to take over Lilco's electricity business.

headline.main: Records Show Lilco Payout Was No Secret

docs.lead_paragraph: SITTING naked on tissue paper, mouth dry, heart flip-flopping, clawing at the plastic hide of the examining table, I do not feel as if I'm in a power position. It's been more than 30 minutes and the paper is adhering, shifting with me. My imagination is metastasizing; the syringes, catheters and scalpels in the cabinet all have my name on them. Finally, a fully-dressed human being marches into the room weary, impatient and, while reading from a folder that really does have my name written on it, demands, ''What seems to be the trouble?''

headline.main: It's Enough to Make You Sick, The Way Patients Get Treated

docs.abstract: Article by Robert Lipsyte chides medical system for problems patients encounter on way to getting treatment; says in his 20 years as cancer patient and as a caregiver he has come to be certain only of this: never seek care without taking healthy spouse or partner with you who has advanced degrees in accounting, diplomacy, law, medicine and comedy; says too often we make journey alone, sick and scared and vulnerable to a medical system that rarely takes time to listen to a history that can insure a future (Special Section: Women's Health) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki began the year with a modest list of things he wanted out of the Legislature: end parole for violent felons, permit charter schools, allow casino gambling, toughen penalties for juvenile criminals. He got none of those. But while the 1998 legislative session, which ended Friday, may look like a bust for the Republican Governor, it gave him a few handy issues to use as he runs for re-election this year, particularly the time-worn theme that Democrats are soft on crime.

headline.main: In Albany, a Year to Turn Defeats Into Election Issues

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY day Marcie Rothman, who is 51, takes three Body Wise Female Advantage nutritional capsules -- an arsenal of 22 ingredients marketed as the natural answer to menopause. Soy protein is a selective estrogen-response modifier meant to stabilize a woman's suddenly dwindling supply of estrogen; along with black cohosh root, it is now a popular way to fight hot flashes. Mexican yam is a trendy natural source of progesterone, and passionflower, valerian root and kava are supposed to ameliorate mood swings.

headline.main: With Alternative Medicine, Profits Are Big, Rules Are Few

docs.abstract: Alternative-remedy industry is now a $4 billion industry, as growing numbers of people dose themselves with nontraditional treatments; women, who buy majority of medicines and medicinal treatments, have dizzying array of products at their disposal, from vitamin supplements to pulverized Chinese herbs; these products do not yet have quantifiable proof either of quality or of effectiveness; no regulatory agency enforces quality control of these supplements, and there are not nearly enough scientific data to confirm that their ingredients do what they profess; drawings (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law recognizes as the ''disease'' of infertility. Lucky? Indisputably. First because Carla, a legal assistant, and Bruce, a real-estate broker, succeeded when the biological odds are stacked against a 41-year-old woman conceiving even with high-tech intervention. Second because Carla's new insurance carrier, U.S. Healthcare, paid for the successful round of blood tests, sonograms, laboratory work, egg harvesting, in-vitro fertilization and implanting the resulting embryos. All this was performed by one of New York City's top reproductive medical teams, which was led by Dr. Cecilia Schmidt-Sarosi and her husband, Dr. Peter Sarosi, reproductive endocrinologists.

headline.main: For Infertility Treatments, Now You're Covered, Now You're Not

docs.abstract: Infertility treatment is an expensive proposition, and health coverage tends to be ephemeral, with companies changing policy with lightning speed; new trend in assisted-reproduction is for private infertility centers that operate without the high overhead of a hospital; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a securities analyst for the brokerage firm Salomon Smith Barney, and one of the first people on Wall Street to specialize in companies focusing on women, Melissa Wilmoth can rattle off demographic facts and figures that show women are becoming a vast and powerful market for medical products. Ms. Wilmoth speaks excitedly about technological breakthroughs and new devices that will improve the treatment of breast and cervical cancers, osteoporosis, incontinence and infertility. And she can reel off a long list of small companies that are developing these new products. So of the two dozen companies in Ms. Wilmoth's area of expertise, how many does she recommend as investments? Two, both of which have business links to her firm.

headline.main: Researchers Finding New Wariness on Wall Street

docs.abstract: Despite facts and figures that show women are becoming vast and powerful market for medical products, Wall Street has taken cautious approach to recommending stocks of women's health companies; Melissa Wilmoth, securities analyst for Salomon Smith Barney and one of first people on Wall Street to specialize in companies focusing on women, says she recommends only two such companies; says 'we're not going to recommend stocks that aren't good investments'; financial track record of many women's health companies is not good, but neither is financial performance of most small medical firms; Wilmoth photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jimmy Bosch is a trombonist who cha-chas with the biggest names in salsa, and his flaring melodies and frantic rhythms energize fans in 35 countries. But at H & H Bagels on West 46th Street, he is just Jim Bosch, the guy who calmly and matter-of-factly takes customer orders, packs bagels and checks inventory. Mr. Bosch, 38, started working there full time in 1992, when his music career stalled, and still comes in four or five afternoons a month.

headline.main: Salsa Trombone at Night, With Bagels by Day
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE

docs.abstract: Profile of Jimmy Bosch, salsa trombonist by night and clerk at H & H Bagels shop in midtown Manhattan by day; phots (M)
